sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
A new genus of the spider family Trachelidae L. Koch, 1872 ,
Cornifronus
gen. nov.
from China is described, as well as one new species,
C. simplex
sp. nov.
(♁ ♀ ), known only from Hainan and Yunnan Province .

sec.p: Key words: Asia , morphology , new species , trachelids , taxonomy

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Trachelids can be easily distinguished by a strong reduction in the number of normal leg spines, and the presence (mostly in males) of blunt ventral legs cusps on the last three apical segments of the anterior legs (
). The presence and absence of leg spines and cusps ventrally on the anterior legs varies greatly among genera. Thirteen of the 23 known genera do not have spines but have cusps, two genera (
Poachelas Haddad & Lyle, 2008
and
Spinotrachelas Haddad, 2006
) have both spines and cusps, six genera ( Coronarachne
, Falcaranea
,
Fuchiba Haddad & Lyle, 2008
,
Fuchibotulus Haddad & Lyle, 2008
,
Planochelas Lyle & Haddad, 2009
and Trachecymbius
) have neither spines nor cusps, and two genera (
Capobula Haddad, Jin, Platnick & Booysen, 2021
and
Orthobula Simon, 1897
) have spines but no cusps.
Capobula
and
Orthobula
are similar in appearance and habits, and
Capobula
was established based on a species removed from
Orthobula
as the type species.

While examining spider specimens collected in Hainan and Yunnan Provinces, China , we found several specimens of trachelids that are similar to
Capobula
and
Orthobula
in body size, habitus, and the presence of paired ventral leg spines on the anterior legs, but have a distinctive horn on the clypeus. After study, we conclude that these specimens represent a new trachelid genus. Therefore,
Cornifronus
gen. nov.
is proposed, including one new species described in this paper.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p:
All measurements are given in millimeters (mm). Leg measurements are shown as total length (femur, patella, tibia, metatarsus, tarsus). Total length is the sum of the carapace and abdomen lengths, regardless of the pedicel. The epigyne was removed and cleared in a pancreatin solution (
), transferred to alcohol and temporarily mounted for illustration.All specimens are preserved in 75% alcohol and were examined, illustrated and measured with a Leica M205A stereomicroscope equipped with an Abbe drawing device. Photographs were captured using a Leica M205A stereomicroscope equipped with a DFC550 CCD camera. The specimens used in this study are deposited in the Museum of Hebei University, Baoding, China (MHBU).

Diagnosis.
Cornifronus
gen. nov.
can be recognized from all other trachelid genera by the middle of the clypeus with a compressed conical horn-like projection (
).
Cornifronus
gen. nov.
is similar to
Capobula
and
Orthobula
in the small body size (less than 3 mm ), the deep pits on the carapace (
), the large number of paired ventral spines on the anterior legs, and the absence of ventral cusps in both sexes (
).

In addition,
Cornifronus
gen. nov.
resembles
Capobula
in having the palpal tegulum not inflated and the small bursae without spherical sclerotized bases, but can be distinguished from it by: 1) abdomen with distinct X-shaped markings and carapace with deep pits over the entire surface (
), whereas abdomen without distinguishing markings and pits absent along the midline of carapace in
Capobula
(
Haddad et al . 2021
: figs 3–10); 2) male palp without patellar apophysis (
), whereas present in
Capobula
(
Haddad et al . 2021
: fig. 49); 3) copulatory ducts extremely short and inconspicuous, whereas long and directed posteriorly in
Capobula
(
;
Haddad et al . 2021
: figs 60, 66); and 4) primary spermathecae posteriorly positioned (
), whereas laterally positioned in the latter (
Haddad et al . 2021
: figs 60, 66).
Cornifronus
gen. nov.
resembles
Orthobula
in having distinct Xshaped markings on abdomen and the absence of a patellar apophysis in male palp, but can be distinguished from it by: 1) palpal tegulum not inflated and its width significantly smaller than the latter (
;
Haddad et al . 2022
: figs 62, 68); 2) embolus uncoiled, whereas finely coiled in
Orthobula
(
;
Haddad et al . 2022
: figs 88, 93); 3) femoral apophysis spine-like and tibial apophysis lamellar (
), whereas respectively finger-like and triangular in
Orthobula
(
Haddad et al . 2022
: figs 63, 69); 4) copulatory openings positioned medially (
,
), while positioned anteriorly in
Orthobula
(
Haddad et al . 2022
: figs 54, 59); and 5) bursae small and without sclerotized bases (
), whereas large and with spherical sclerotized bases in the latter (
Haddad et al . 2022
: figs 55, 60).
Etymology. The genus name is a combination of the Latin words corniger , meaning horned, and frons , meaning clypeus, referring to the clypeus with a horned projection. Gender is masculine.

Composition. Known only from the type species,
Cornifronus simplex
sp. nov.
.
Distribution. Hainan and Yunnan provinces of China .
Habitat. All the specimens were collected in leaf litter on the ground.
